text: A total hidden place that's located in the basement of an office building. No frills type of place that offers authentic Korean eats! Upon my first visit I was feeling a little bit of a variety so I tried the  kimchi soup, bibimbap, and pho (both the meatball and steak). I definitely would stick to Korean when coming here; although they offer Pho, the flavors didn't seem as authentic as typical Pho places. The pho broth was flavorful but it was the meat that threw me off... Back to the stars here; focus on that spicy, tangy, and full of meat and veggies Kim chi soup! This soup will compete with the top soups of there as it has just the right amount of spice, enough ingredients to make it filling, and perfect on a colder day! Their bibimbap also was a hit as it was  packed with fresh veggies and enough variety to keep even the most pickiest of palettes pleased.  If you're in the loop and craving a quick Korean bite, make sure you swing by here!
I ordered Pho and Bibimbob. Satisfied. Very good. This place was hard to find though..

This is my favorite Korean restaurant in downtown! The food is very good and stuffs are really nice! Highly recommend  (gomtang) here! For people who don't like to eat artificial food this is the right spot!

What is it about Korean food that makes it so addicting? Well this place is close to work and satisfies my bibimbop cravings! I keep meaning to try the pho but once I get there I just have to have the bibimbop. Yum!

The one of the best pho in Chicago downtown was right there. The taste made me remember my grandma's beloved dinner when I was 7 years old. I satisfied both tastes and price. There is also a option for vegetarians and a bunch of Korean style stews.

For being a Korean fast-casual spot in the Loop, this underground place is good enough for me! I had the bibimbap bowl (about $8.95): The portion size was pretty good, it came with all the classic toppings and the taste was pretty authentic. They also serve kimchi (the spicy pickled cabbage side), but that cost is extra (sad face). This place is not found outside on the street. You'll have to enter a building, follow the signs and go downstairs to find this. It shares space with 2 other fast casual spots. There is probably enough seating for maybe 10-20 people, mostly small tables. The food came out pretty quick, so this was perfect for lunch.

The name is skeptical! Should not order pho here. If your name has pho in it, the pho better be on point. The pho wasn't good, not authentic, and they put too much noodle in the bowl which ruins the broth. Anyway, this restaurant is Korean owned, so you should order the Korean food. My dish that I ordered was the kimchi stew, which was delicious.
The kimchi stew is awesome!! This place is a few blocks from my work, and it is a great spot for a quick, inexpensive, tasty meal. It is a pretty good spot for authentic Korean food downtown!

This hidden gem came to me on a hungry lunch day. Downtown can be quite overwhelming with all of the choices you have. Anything you feel like eating seems like it is just around the corner. Which I found to be seriously true. I was this sign affixed on to a building saying "green apple PHOever" with an arrow pointing down into the building. This place is located in the downstairs of a random building so you wouldn't be able to see it from street level. If you blink, you might miss it.  I get the special pho, it comes with meatballs and sliced brisket. The only thing I wished was tat it came with more meatballs since mine always comes with just one. The pricing isn't too bad considering that we are downtown. They also serve Korean rice plates such as Bibimbap, bugolgi with rice and veggies. The service is super quick and with all of the accouterments. As you might already know, I enjoy doctoring up my pho and it is conveniently on the table to add to my pho as I please. I like this place and its a great place to go for a quick bite to eat and not too hard on the pockets. Nothing too fancy for lunch, its perfect!
Enjoyed my meal.  It is kinda of awkward getting to and dining area is dated.  Food was good and service was prompt.

I've had the chicken bibimbap and the seafood pho here. Both were okay, but my seafood pho had little actual seafood meat.  My coworkers come here a lot and enjoy the soups, so it's a safe bet for lunch during the winter. The place itself is a bit hidden since it's located in the basement level of some building, but there is ample seating space down there. It's great for those 3+ people lunch groups since the tables can easily be joined together.

awesome bibimbap! Even more flavor when you pick the spicy chicken on top of it. Their japchai also very satisfying but light and flavorful with veggies and lots of green onions. Their chicken pho with vegetables is the best thing to eat when you're hungry but need energy and a pick me up. My favorite thing about this Korean joint is their service and attitude with which they serve-i feel their warmth and hospitality. I usually cook-but when I don't bring lunch to work-this is always my go to place :)
Good pho, and great value. Quick and cheap. Lots of noodles and extras and they pack it up nicely to go.

This place was tough to find if you aren't familiar with the city, which was my case. The place is in a food court downstairs from an office building. Has a lot of double tables and is generally clean.  The food is great! But what I love the most is that it was extremely fast! Great place to get a quick lunch, specially on a cold day!

New guy at the office in the Windy City. It's cold and rainy outside. Lunch time rolls around. Guy in the cube over from me goes... Dave, you're asian! You must do Pho! Let's do Pho! Being a fat kid in a small asian boy's body, I didn't have to be persuaded.  This is the most random place ever (then again, still new to the Chicago). This eatery is in the basement of an office building. Like, in the basement. ARE YOU SERIOUS? I was extremely skeptical and questioned reviews from my coworkers and my fellow Yelpers. Well, I was was wrong. I was very wrong Yelp and I'm damn glad for it.  The pho was very good. I had some lingering skepticism when I saw there was Korean writing on the menu for the pho, but I guess it's both a pho and Korean food shop. So I ordered the Dac Biet, the you got everything including the tripe that makes a bunch of people all squirmy.  The pho bowl came out very quick and the portion was huge. I'd like to think I have normal sized hands, but the bowl was uuuuuuge.  Now to the point: -Big portion -Good broth -Thin style rice noodles -Ample amount of proteins -big portion of the garnishes, no basil tho :( Pros:  -Close to the office -quick service -Good value  -Pretty solid bowl of pho Cons: -Seating is plentiful, but still gladiator style -No  basil Final thoughts: Will I come back? Yes, absolutely. Is it better than my mom's?Hell no. Will it allow me to regain my asian powers and beat the windy/wet/cold Chicago weather? Oh hell yeah.
They have moved... the yelp map is accurate.. Enter the building... foodcourte is downstairs.   It as excellent as ever!
Great Pho!  Fresh and fast.  Have been twice and had the chicken pho both times.  The broth is flavorful and veggies are fresh.  Great for a cold day or really any day.
Not bad. Kinda confusing where the location is. Yelp's gps sucks. Overall food is B+ will visit again
A wonderful lunch spot in the basement in the loop. The service is so extremely quick and the food is two thumbs up.

Wonderful find! It's located in a basement in the heart of the Loop, but impressive seating area once you get there. There were Vietnamese and Korean options, and we went for the pho when we visited. HUGE PORTIONS. With the price we paid, we really didn't expect the portions that it came in. The taste was nothing super special, but the price/quantity ratio is amazing. We also loved that it seems to be owned & operated by an elderly Asian couple -- we love supporting small local businesses!  We went for Saturday lunch. Don't know how the crowds are during week days (especially lunch hours), but considering that most businesses are closed on the weekends in the Loop, this is a good, quick fix if you find yourself in the area on the weekends.
Quick, simple pho with great flavor.  Love the dingy food court vibe- something very warm and nostalgic about it

Quick fix for pho in the loop. If you have a hankering for soup noodles, you can get your fix here. Deep in the basement of an office building, you might be skeptical of the food here. Interesting set up as one of two restaurants, the other being a Mexican joint that also looked interesting. While you can pick b/n some Korean or Viet dishes, I went with the combination pho to get a little taste of everything. The price is fine for the portion you get. The food came in short order and it was hot. Overall, the noodles were satisfactory and the broth was well flavored. My only complaint was the lack of meats. Small pieces of each and not the same as some of the more traditional pho I've had. I'd rate this a 3 star, however, given the location and lack of choices in the loop, I opted for a 4 star. I believe this place is more Korean food first, then Viet. That being said, I'd like to try some of the bibimbap/chop chae options next time. -Smile when you order
It's not real vietnamese pho.  It's korean style pho with broccoli and carrots which I'm not used to having in my pho.  The broth doesn't taste anything like the "normal" pho.

Not the best pho I've ever had but not bad. Portion is huge and service was fast. Will be back on cold days and when I have a cold.  Important to note that it is located in the basement of 150 not on the street.
Very nice and delicious! We ate pho, kimchi stew and bibimbab with beef. I love all food!

Only stopped in once to get out of the cold and was encouraged by the Yelp star rating.  However, I was disappointed in both the service and food.  I came in before lunch time and had to flag the server down to order.  They seemed to understand my order and repeated it back to me, but then I got the wrong entree.  I was so hungry that I didn't bother to complain.  The food itself was somewhat bland. The price wasn't worth what I got, but the location was convenient. Plus, they have free wifi and I was fortunate to find an outlet to charge my phone.  Definitely, wouldn't recommend this place unless you are in the area and desperate.

*** Note: Order through the Ritual app and bypass the line *** It was not incredibly busy when I came here on Monday around noon. It's not exactly the most easy place to find, but you walk down the stairs into a food court to find it on your left.  I was torn between ordering the pho, bibimbap, or bulgogi. In the end, I decided on the Chicken Bibimbap. It comes in a massive bowl that's bigger than your face and gochujang sauce on the side (despite lacking the option on the Ritual app). I know this is definitely not authentic by any means, but the food was very underwhelming unfortunately. The chicken didn't taste that fresh, and the vegetables were lacking. There was way too much sauce slathered onto the chicken that didn't marinate well enough. The service was decent though. Despite a busy line, the cashier didn't ignore me and kept me updated on my order. At $10.02 for very subpar food, I'd say check out other options in the loop.

The pho here was pretty good. The lime they gave was really juicy, which I appreciated because I hate when I get a stupid dry, unsqueezable lime. I got the combination and there were no rare beef slices in that one, so I'd probably want a pho with more rare beef next time. That being said, soup and noodles were pretty good.  IMPORTANT PSA: this doesn't reflect on the business/food itself, but I got my wallet stolen here yesterday while my head was stuck in my bowl of pho. The lunch crowd around me seemed to be mostly young professionals meeting friends for lunch, so I definitely had let my guard down...I found my purse unzipped and my wallet gone by the time I got up to left. Again, not a reflection on this business itself but just a warning to future patrons.

I was in the middle of catching a cold and discovered this place right when I needed a piping hot bowl of pho! It's not the best I ever had, but it certainly got the job done. The bowl is HUGE and was way too big for me to finish. The place is busy at lunch, but they move fast and there are tons of tables if you choose to stay there and eat.
I ordered the chicken bibimbap which was average. They kind of skimped on all of the veggies. It was like 3 leaves of spinach. Service is fast though.

Maybe 1 star is a bit harsh because I've haven't actually been to this restaurant bc.. it's never open!!!! How's the food?  Who knows?  They.  Are.  Never.  Open. How's the service?  Who knows?  I've never made it past the front door. Seriously guys, post your actual hours, not some imaginary facsimile of an actual restaurants hours.

Pretty decent for a quick soup craving, couldn't find too many Asian spots around that part of city. I had the kimchi stew which was more spicy than I'm used to. My cousin had the beef pho which was just good but satisfying. And then we were quickly out of there to keep exploring the windy city.

This place totally surprised me. At first I didn't even know where it was located and then I saw the sign just under the DD banner. I knew this place was good when i noticed the line. The location gives it such a city vibe that is amazing. I ordered the bulgogi whilst my cousin got the seafood Ph. I was very pleased at the tastes that I experienced here. If you're looking for a Ph fix or some fast Korean head to this place. Next time I'm in town, I will be returning.
Hard to find but food was so good:-) And cheap enough! I definitely would go there again!

Trying to understand how yelpers are giving this place a 5 star rating? You must have a palate of a goat. The pho is nothing to rave about. No sense of depth, flavor or element. You can smell the spices but it's not bold enough to taste. Therefore the flavor comes out extremely bland, fishy and salty. Fishy because they use fish sauce in the broth so you end up tasting mostly fish sauce broth. I was extremely unimpressed and would love to give them another shot, there's obviously lots of work needed in the broth. Owners, take notes.  Can't believe people rave to say this place is better than places in Argyle. This is a mixed fusion spot that's known for their Korean dishes, not Vietnamese. Stick to what you're good at.

This place is pretty Meh... The food wasn't great, very bland. Its located in a basement which was a bit getto, but I looked past that to give it a shot. I was fairly disappointed. I got the bibimbap, and it was one of the worst I have had at a restaurant. It felt "fast foodish", well since it was, but it seems like they didn't put much effort into it.

Located on the lower floor on Madison. There is sitting inside. It is a bit quiet without background  music, but food makes up for it.  Had Japche multiple times there and each time it was great and it took less than 10 minutes for my order (it was before lunch hour rush).

Loved this spot for lunch! I ordered the chicken bibimbap and it was delicious, not to mention generous portions. The service was also extremely quick and the lunch was affordable. I can't wait to come back and try the pho.

3.5 stars for this place.  We got the chicken bibimbap and my pho. The broth of pho was a bit salty, and the rice noodles might be over cooked, so was the meat. The bibimbap was better.  Services were good. The lady at the order place was quite nice, and our food were served quickly.

Lucky to have this place right next to my office. The beef broth is so rich and yummy it totally satisfied my pho craving for a late lunch :) the meat was a little scarce but I haven't found a great pho place in Chicago yet and flavor of the broth was just so so good I can't say I didn't love it. The location is a little ghetto... Downstairs next to a Dunkin Donuts.. But isn't that where all the hidden pho gems are??  I'm definitely coming back. It's run by the sweetest Korean guy. Reminded me of my uncle :)

From the spicy tofu to the phô everything was amazing! Eggs perfectly cooked, smoothies freshly made, and all our needs accommodated for. I loved all of it, and the staff was incredibly courteous and kind!

This place is a hidden gem for cheap, great eats in the city. It's downstairs, connected to a dunkin' donuts. The food is great. I got gomtang beef soup which was amazing. The bibimbap and pho is on point too.  The cashier/(owner I think) has kind of spotty English but he's a really nice guy. Would recommend!

Best pho in downtown! Their broth is beef-based and its got very deep taste to it. First spoon of the soap always makes my day! I was intimidated by the price at first but the portion was more than satisfying. Also recommend their korean veggie bowl with rice, bulgogie and spice chicken. They are usually very fast serving Highly recommended!

Overall rating*: BURN THIS PLACE DOWN! Visits: 3 Food - 1/5 - Took them over 20 minutes for them to provide what can only be described as very mediocre Korean food. Had the Pho here before as well, it was remarkably disappointing. Might as well just stay home and eat a bowl of flavorless noodles. People - 1/5 - Had no clue what they were doing. Person taking orders kept writing the same numbers on the orders so people's plates were getting confused. They also lost orders and looked bewildered. Barely an apology for my order taking about 5 times longer than it should have. Management - 1/5 - Nonexistent, staff was running around with no direction. Ambiance - 1/5 - Imagine eating in a dingy garage. You got it.  *Overall Ratings are: Burn This Place Down, Skip It, Meh, Pretty Damn Good, & An Absolute Must Try

Complete rip off.... Bibimbop this is NOT. STINGY portion, 90% of which was White rice, with stringy beef and "meh" vegetables.  A few spinach stems, iceberg lettuce, $10 and not even a beverage.  Pass.

They have my favorite PHO, with seafood. Absolutely delicious (except the fishball could taste weird sometimes...). Their broth is different from what you have at other PHO places. It is more salty, more concentrated and I love it. They also serve the soup with cilantro instead of basil, which in my opinion tastes 10x better in PHO. I have never tried their Korean food but must check their PHO. Great people!

Located at the lower floor. The entry is located on Madison.  You order at the counter then the food is servered on a tray later according the number you get. We tried outt the beef pho and Bibimbap. It was quite interesting to see the Korean food and Vienamese food at the same place.  Both pho soup and Bibimbap are decent but not outstanding. The broth in the pho soup were pretty good and noodles were cooked right. The meat was a bit dry. Bibimbap was lacking the veggies I expected. The flavor was greate. The services were pretty good. And there are plenty tables to sit. It is always good to be able to have some Asian food during the lunch hours.
I tried the spicy tofu and ... not so much.  There wasn't really much spice or seasoning to speak of.

I really like this place.  It is located in a dingy basement setting, which can be a little off putting. The standout here is the Pho. If you want Pho in the loop, this is your best bet. You get a giant bowl with most of the standard fixings you'd find in a legitimate, Vietnamese-run Pho shop on Argyle (basil, sprouts, lime, jalipeno, etc). The Korean food they serve is decent, and has never left me feeling disappointed. Their Kimchi stew is really nice, as is the soybean stew. Both of these usually come with rice and a side dish. Not too shabby!

I love this place!! I'm so glad they are still in business after their previous building shut down. I was able to get gomtang soup here but they stopped serving it. Anyhow, they have the best pho I've ever had and their portions are perfect. They are now on Madison right behind a Bank of America Bank branch in the lower level. The owners are very courteous and gracious to all of their customers.

I'm definitely not an expert, but this place is good. I got the chicken and vegetable pho, and the broth was super flavorful. There were so many vegetables in it that made it very colorful. However, there wasn't a lot of chicken in it, and what was in it, was dry. It was $11, but I got a huge bowl, and I will definitely get another meal out of it. Will definitely go back to try out other things on the menu.

They moved by the Chase building! And it's cold! So I decided to try something other than Pho, which is still pretty okay in my book if you're jonsin' for some in the loop. The Kimchi stew, mannnn....THE KIMCHI STEW! That is where it's at. It reminds me a lot of the Vietnamese Pickled Mustard Soup - if you're Viet, you'll know what I'm talking about. It's like ultimate comfort food and totally hit the spot on this single digit degree weather. I couldn't even wait for the stew to cool down, basically burning the roof of my mouth while eating it. I don't EVEN care. So good.

Words cannot describe how happy I am to find out this place is back!! I don't care if it's not dirt cheap or there's better pho in argyle. I need good lunch in downtown Chicago and this place is by far the best for me. No more cold sandwich or salad every day. My mom in Korea will be so excited to know that I'm eating some good healthy warm lunch on weekdays. Oh and the new place is a lot bigger and cleaner than the previous location, which was a hideous food court in the filthy building.

This little underground area is the perfect spot to start expanding the much needed authentic Asian restaurants needed in the loop.  Kick that Dunkin Donuts out (come on Chicago, there's one every 3 feet) and have more little Asian food court places like this.  I ordered the kimchi stew and it was satisfying but to be honest I was really turned off by the price.  It's your standard kimchi stew with just a few strips of pork served with a little bowl of rice.  The price was about $11.  I think it should come with at least one banchan. Although expensive, the flavor was spot on and I'd be lying if I said that I wouldn't be back.  I was hesitant to get the pho because of some of the other reviews said it lacked any flavor but walking down the stairs, you don't smell coffee from the Dunkin' right next to it, you smell pho broth and the accompanying garnishes.  Is there a pho broth candle? There should be.

Service is very good, super friendly people there. Lots of sitting space. Food is good for the price. I don't know many quick Asian places in downtown anyways. Good for a quick lunch break. There's no server, they take the meal to your table but you take your tray back. Corn tea is on the house, and very relaxed, no rush sense sitting there. I usually stay a few hours working on homework or reading and they don't care.

Really want to like this place and give a good review, but it was very underwhelming.  Got the bulgogi on a Friday lunch, for here.  The meat came from a warming station, so not made to order. The flavor was very plain and generic. Neither sweet nor salty, nor very bulgogi at all.  The portion of meat was satisfactory, but the heap of white rice was not enough. Ran out half way through. Comes with side of garden salad too.  No kimchi on the side? Needs it.  The white rice was also very poorly done. The quality overall is on par with Lai Lai, and at $10 for the meal, leaves me wishing there was a legit Korean option near the loop.

Pho in Chicago- this is probably as good as you are going to get. I'm a very big fan of pho. This isn't the best I've had nor is it the worst. If you haven tried pho you really need to. I wish they had basil and fish sauce, but at least you get cilantro instead. I'm definitely a repeat customer. And when its cold- at least twice a week
I have a belly full of take-out pho. Portion was quite good for takeout and the broth holds up against a lot of the pho restaurants in the city. I am completely satisfied.

My absolutely favorite lunch place Inthe loop! Pho is delicious and filling, can't wish for me.  Their other meals were good as well. it's a long way for me to their new location, but I go there once a week anyway.

Food taste and quality is consistent with my prior review. This is the only legit Korean/Pho spot, so by default it's the best in the loop. However, prices have gone up, so expect to spend $11 after tax here for an entree, which is sort of obnoxious for a quick lunch. Location is much closer in the Loop center now so that's a plus for me (especially in the winters)! Location is easy to find.

Tried out the pho for lunch yesterday. Things looked odd as soon as they brought the tray of soup to my table. There was no basil to be found! The only garnishes were cilantro, sprouts, a lime wedge, and two pieces of jalapeño. I tried to roll with it, but the broth was pretty weak, and meat/tripe scant. This place is close enough to my work that I would probably give their Korean offerings a shot, but they've lost my pho business going forward for sure. If it's in the name of your restaurant, you better be good at it.

I was so disappointed when I showed up at the old location and it was closed, but was lightened by the fact that there was a piece of paper on the door with a new address.  I hustled over there but another sign said it would open in January.  So, I waited.  I had a cold and cough today and was craving pho so I headed over.   The pho was as good and rich and authentic as before.  The new dive food court is in a basement next to dunkin donuts.  The Green Apple has a slightly fancier décor than before. It's not the best pho I've ever had (Vancouver, with about a dozen different combinations of cuts of meat and done-ness of cooking, and broth so hot they could serve you raw slices and you could cook them by submerging them), but it's the best (only?) in the loop.  Other dishes are authentic Korenamese, respectively, so you better have the stomach for that before ordering. Glad they are back.

The new location inside Dunkin Donuts location on Madison is perfect! Great Korean food for lunch. Introduced my colleagues to this place and for most it was the first time trying Korean food. I'm Korean and I have no hesitation recommending Green Apple PHOever. Pho is very good too.

Oh how I missed this place while it was closed for moving for few weeks. This place is a must stop for me whenever I am visiting Windy city. Authentic homemade style of various korean dishes to mildly flavored pho. It is always a difficult decision to choose. The service is also friendly. I strongly recommend pho on a chilly and raining days. Just fills you up with satisfying smile the portion is appropriate. It was initially a challenge to locate the new location but once you find it, this place will be cemented to your memory.

This was truly the worst Korean food I have ever had. I had to ask that the spicy chicken be reheated as it appeared to have been from the refrigerator. The rice was also of poor quality. Yelp let me down on this one.
I couldn't finish my food. The main ingredient of the bulgogi must have been salt as it was the only thing I could taste. Stay away!

Horrible Pho: 1) half-cooked noodles 2)9$ for half the quality and quantity from anything from argyle. 3)broth felt microwaved 4)opposite of fresh 5)doesn't serve complementary cup of water  6)I wasted 9$ QQ
Please come back!  This is the best place to get pho and gom tang in the loop!

LOVE this place, but went today and it was closed...so was the entire upper floor of the food court?!  what happened?   I usually go once or twice a week during the winter, less so in the summer since I pretty much only eat the pho (I do loves me some bi bim bap but can't resist pho)  Seriously...I'll hold my breath till it comes back.

I'm generally a fan of eating Korean Food served from dive locations. Why? Because it just feels more authentic to me that way.  The Green Apple is just such a place. Their modern looking to-go counter is tucked away on the second floor of a food court that looks like my grandma's kitchen.  They serve authentic Korean dishes at a fair price, mostly under $10.  The beef bibimbap was delicious. Next time I'll try the cold glass noodles for a refreshing summer lunch and in the winter I'll be back for some hearty kimchi and pork stew.  My only complaint is that the meal didn't come with any banchan (small pickled veggie side dishes).

Well this place came out of nowhere. I forgot my lunch at home today, so I forlornly stumbled to the weird food court next to my work in search of something to eat that wouldn't make me sick. I am a big Pho fan, so I thought, "why not?" Little did I know I would be eating the best Pho I have ever had. When you don't have to put any Sriracha or those other sauces in (I forget their names) you know the pho is good. The Vietnamese community seems to agree, as the tables were packed out with many Vietnamese people. I mean, I lived in Southeast Asia and never had pho this good.  Go eat it!

Ordered the beef bibimbab and paid for extra beef, still got very little beef. When I complained I was told I had gotten extra beef and that they normally put a third of what I'd gotten. How hard would it have been to give me some extra beef? Sorry not coming back. There's just no beef here.

I was visiting on business, with my friend from Korean and other from London. We wanted Korean bbQ close by. This place came up and was walking distance. We had a little trouble finding it at first and when we did we weren't sure we were in the right place. It's in a cafeteria style setting with lots of other restaurants. We were wary but determined. Our friend from Korea ordered us Bibimbap because we didn't know what was authentic or not. She said this dish was most authentic dish since not an actually bbq place. She spoke Korean with the service gentleman which made us feel like this was the real deal. She said it is. She talked to the guy. The dish was amazing. You add your own amount of the sweet spicy sauce. The only thing she said was that the egg was supposed to come raw and then cook in a clay hot bowl. We didn't have that but it was awesome. Probably some sort of food service code... The price was outstanding for the quality and quantity. The gentleman was so kind to serve us at near by tables. He felt a rapport with my friend for sure. She order Teriyaki! Irony! Said it was a 4 but not a 5. Highly recommend!  Helpful to have someone speak Korean, but not required. Just don't expect a restaurant.

Worst Korean good ever! Pho's so bad~~ pho's better at Tank! Portion, flavor... Everything... Worth the trip For Korean Food, it's better to go to Tozi (1265 N Milwaukee) where they have excellent Korean food & has lunch special too! Can even BBQ during lunch! Lots of choices, there's no 'lunch portion' for lunch special prices... Try it yourself, you'll understand why tozi's way better!

I love this place!  The owner is a quiet old man and it is otherwise staffed by friendly Korean guys in their late teens and 20's. I am a big eater of Korean food (not a pho fan in general), but usually Korean food isn't cheap, especially at my neighborhood restaurant (Cafe Corea-- also delicious).   But this place is super cheap, at entrees around ~$8 I highly recommend the items I have so far tried: * The tofu/pork kimchi stew (filled with kimchi and generous  *Carrot juice (surprisingly, really fresh and delicious, offsets the spicy food well) Edit: came back and the bimbimbap was not fresh or good. Lowering the rating.
I guess the owner has been charged, and I got the worst Pho Dac Viet in my life. The rice noodle is not fully cooked, and filled just half of a bowl... Not much to eat... Don't go there!

A lot of people come here for the Pho, it's not the best Pho but it's very good and the best you'll get in the area without breaking the bank.  The only small downside is that they charge 50 cents extra for a 'To go' item.  The family that runs the place is very nice and service is very good.  They are Korean so they do have a Korean menu too.  It's authentic and quite good.  I'd recommend the Korean soups in the winter time.  If you are going to eat at the food court, try to avoid the noon rush.  If you are picky about ambiance, you might want to take out.
not authentic. soup incredibly salty . weird meatballs. actual noodles were good though.

The Pho was good, especially for the price but nothing spectacular. This place is great for a quick, cheap lunch that isn't your typical fast food. Next time I'll definitely be trying all the Korean dishes. The atmosphere has the most opportunity as it's located in a somewhat run down food court.

I was super excited for there to be a pho joint downtown, especially one where you could get lunch for $8.25 with tax.  That's becoming a rare thing these days in the Loop!    I'm vegetarian, so I got the vegetable pho a couple of times thinking it would be suitable for my diet.  Welp, I found a piece of meat in the broth and I asked them what the stock was made out of...  It's beef broth.  I've seen a few people comment here about the vegetarian option at this restaurant and, well, there is no vegetarian option at this restaurant.  Buyer beware.  I guess it's back to Chipotle.

In Chicago for the week, the throat is a little sore and that dangly thing at my throat is a little swollen. What do I need? The Asian's answer for chicken soup...PHO! Looked around yelp and saw that this place had decent reviews plus it was close to my office.  Did I have high hopes that this would match up to the Pho Bangs and the other great Vietnamese shops in NY, not really.  What I can say is that this was my first Pho in Chicago and it wasn't bad. My go to Pho bowl in NY is the number 1 XL. Closest match is the P5 at Green Apple. Price wise, it costs a couple bucks more here and smaller than what I'm used to. Other than that, the broth was delicious and warmed my sore throat. The noodles were as I expected them to be. As for the meats, it wasn't much to look at because there wasn't much in the bowl. I did like the surprise of a beef tendon ball thrown in. This bowl was missing tripe, tendon and a extra few slices of beef eye of round. The amount if brisket they gave was just about right. Who knew Koreans making Pho would be this good? Would I come back? You betcha! Gotta try the Korean stuff next time.

It's a nice little gem for standard Korean food & Vietnamese pho. Prices are pretty good for what you get in a downtown location.  I actually wish they had small/large bowl options.  As it stands, the pho are pretty standard. The nice old couple that runs this place is awesome.  I'll definitely be back here for pho as it's convenient and a respectable place.  Reasons why it's not a 5 stars - meats are over cooked and a few times chewy, seafood items (esp shrimp) are small, broth needs more flavor (maybe 4-5 more hours on the simmer). PS.  Yelp text handler won't let me spell pho properly with the special o :X.

Battling the forces of a growing cold, I ventured into this interesting food court guided by my trusty friend. Inside was a wonderland of ethnic cuisine, from Korean to Mediterranean to Mexican. All of the choices seemed interesting, but we decided to go to the place he recommended, the Green Apple (which is a pretty interesting choice for a Vietnamese/Korean inspired food court stand).  My friend ordered the bibimbap, but I had noticed that a majority of the patrons were ordering the pho. Knowing that pho is a powerful ally against growing colds, I decided to order up a nice hot bowl to warm me up in the frozen tundra of this February Chicago day.  As soon as our food came out, I noticed the disparity in the portion sizes between his bibimbap and my pho. I had clearly won out on this deal. The pho was sizable, and contained quite a bit of noodles and soup. While the meat that was promised in the order was quite meger, the order did come with two types of hot sauces, hoisen sauce, sprouts, lime, and cilantro (which was quite impressive for food court pho). The soup base was not bad. It was served piping hot, and was strong enough to chase the cold away (without being too salty). The noodles were also pretty impressive considering the location. They had a little bit of chewiness, and went well with the soup. Now is it the best pho ever? No, not at all. But in the Loop for $8 bucks? That's actually quite a deal. My friend was quite disappointed in his bibimbap, which barely had any meat, and was overall a lackluster experience for him.  Green Apple isn't going to blow you away with the flavors or with the noodles, but it definitely hits the spot on a lunch break. The $8 price tag on this big bowl of noodles is sweet (especially in the Loop). I definitely will frequent this spot on my lunch break in the future whenever the soup noodle cravings hit (which is pretty much always).

Fast service excellent food and value. I have to admit this this was my first pho experience so I don't have much to compare to. That being said, it was exactly what I wanted it to be. I had the p1 with beef and tripe. The broth was hardy and flavorful even without condiment. Exactly what ya need on a cold winter day

Hidden Asian gem in the middle of the city. Everything is dirt cheap. Can get a great meal for under $8. I really enjoy the sun du bu and kimchi stew with pork. Their marinated meats are good too, but i prefer the marinated spicy pork at the Korean place on the first floor (next to Mickey D's). I can't wait to try their Pho.  Warning: key word HIDDEN gem. The food court is located inside an office building and Green Apple is on the second floor.

You know it's good (the pho) when its so packed for lunch in such a crappy building. I hope the owners of the building don't kick them out as with all the other tenants that have left. Edit: apparently all the tenants are required to leave as developers are turning the location into a hotel; that is, after these developers are done suing each other for money (see  chicagobusiness.com/real… ) I hope Green Apple finds a good home.

Had the Phone for lunch, not bad, not great not very flavorful or much meet. But place has distinct advantage of being in loop where there are not many other better options for Vietnamese food. So I'll ply be back, but if you know of a better one, please let me know.

The food court was definitely poorly lit and dining area was depressing. But with that said, this review is based on the availability & quality of the cuisine in the Loop area.  It is always encouraging to find that majority of the patrons are Asians when going to an Asian food place.  Ordered the P1 Dac Biet for $7.45: Broth, noodles, scallions, onions, steak, flank, tripe, and brisket. The bowl is large, there is ample amount of noodles and broth. There is probably 2 slices of steak, flank, & brisket with a small quarter size amount of tripe. The price for this is pretty low considering the location, but high considering the lack of protein. The noodles were cooked perfectly. The broth, while most yelp description has been "light & tasty" , I would argue that it's a pretty weak broth.  The soul of pho is the broth and you want to have the subtle hints of cinnamon, cloves, fennel, and star anise in the broth. In addition, you get a small plate of bean sprouts, lime, jalapeño, and cliantro to add on your own.  If you have a need for pho, this will fill your stomach, but not the craving. The plus side is when you leave the cafe, felling full... you don't smell like the broth.

It was ridiculous trying to find this place. I was expecting an office building based on other Yelp reviews but NO it's in a food court building. Look for the signs after Lake St for Subway and K-Kitchen and walk to the second floor and you'll find Green Apple. My food was pretty damn good! I'm a vegetarian so I got the vegetable pho. I wanted the kimchi stew without pork but was told they wouldn't take it out. I went during lunch hours when it was hella packed. I'm giving this place 4 stars because of location, crazy busy ambiance, and lack of flexibility for vegetarians.  I'll try other things on the menu next. The fried tofu looked good.
Great options of noodle soups. Fast, friendly staff and the soup was very good. Now the place is busy during lunch time. The positive side they bring the order to you (if you eat there).

An excellent option in the Loop. Somewhat hidden but easy to return to once discovered.  Variety Korean and Vietnamese dishes to choose from.  Now that winter I'd coming,  the pho is always an excellent choice for price, taste and comfort.

In a food court in the middle of an office building, is where you'll find this food stand. This is one of the few places in the loop that makes decent Pho, even though it's a Korean grill place. The pho is tasty but instead of a mint veggie plate, which is the norm, it comes with a cilantro veggie plate. The chopsticks are small and wooded and is too flimsy for the pho noodles. I find it funny that there is a $.50 Extra charge for takeout unless you bring your own bowl.  The other half of the menu is Korean, and it looks tasty but the allure of Pho wins each time I'm here. One day I'll take the dive into the Korean side.

5 stars are not enough to express my feeling about this place! I had Pho tai which I normally order whenever I go pho restaurants and It was the most delicious pho I've ever had!! Super yummy. the broth is just awesome. no artificial flavor at all. I asked what they use to make the broth and they said they put more than  20 natural ingredients in there. As my in Laws run the restaurants I know how it is such a time consuming to make something like that.  Me and my  friend also ordered Bibimbap  which is the most famous Korean food, and omg.. It came in a big portion and of course it was Delicious!  I am in love with this place. I wish I live close to there. If I go to downtown again I will definitely stop by this place again!  Just to want to note that Green Apple is on the second floor of the food court.
The Chicken Pho was delicious, and I am so happy to now have a place to get pho in the Loop. Great service, too.

For the Chicago Loop, this is the best Pho you can find.  Portion is large, they give you 3 different kinds of hot sauce and plenty of toppings. I usually get the Chicken Vegetable Pho. They are a little dingy on the chicken and I don't think they use the best chicken out there and I've also caught Tofu in it before (Not a fan of tofu!) I do suggest they find better quality meat for their Pho. It'd make their restaurant a 5 star place. Nonetheless, the owners are the sweetest and very generous.  Will be back.
ita was just perfect. At first I was afraid, since is located at a fast food area, and is kind of fast food. but all the ingridients are fresh and the phonis delicious
Green Apple does the job if you are looking for pho or korean food. It's not the best but it's not the worst. The food court is dingy, but no one comes here for the atmosphere.

Some of the best Pho I have eaten in my life, and I've eaten a lot of it! Pho Tai was amazing, big portions, fair price, dining in experience was great! Everything is perfect except the ambiance of the food court is meh. But if you want some amazing Pho, this is your spot!

The name of the restaurant is confusing, the food court is dingy, and there are better Vietnamese and Korean restaurants in Chicago, certainly. But for the money, this is easily one of the best lunch options in the Loop. I usually get the vegetarian pho--maybe they're stingier with the meat phos, but the veggie one always has tons of vegetables and the noodles are cooked perfectly. (FYI, as far as I'm concerned, the sriracha and hoisin are NOT optional.) On the Korean side, I love the soybean stew, which is wonderfully spicy. On warm days the best option is bibimbap, which makes up for the lack of a hot stone bowl with a huge variety of vegetables. Overall the portions are very generous for the price.  (Note that Green Apple is on the second floor of the food court. Don't confuse it with the Korean/Thai place on the first floor--it's not nearly as good!)

Yes, I know I've reviewed you before but I only write again because I want everyone to know about your healing and mighty-delicious chicken pho. Hangover. Cold. Good day. Bad day. Week day. Rainy day. Hot summer day. Frigid day in February. You name it, Green Apple will brighten your day with a bowl of their piping hot and refreshing pho. I've had many o' bowls of pho and am confident in saying this is one of the best. Why? 1.) the broth. It's all about the broth. The fat content appears to be lower with a lighter, less-guilt ridden taste to it; 2.) location - despite being geographically located in one of the most hustling and bustling areas of Chicago, you have this way of being a hidden gem via your second floor location in the atrium of a downtown corporate building (I like to pretend I'm the only one who knows about you) For $7.50 you make my day every time I visit.  Also available at Green Apple: other varieties of pho, smoothies and juices, complimentary water jug and plentiful shared seating with the other 5 to 7 restaurants in the building.

Good lunch spot in the loop. Only place where they authenticate basic Korean dishes for the Chicago loop 9-5ers. Prices are reasonable as well. They also have pho which I prefer over Saigon Sisters any day. Ambiance is functional. Open seating in a food court on the second floor.

Tried the soybean stew this time and was very pleased. Not exactly a sundubu as it wasn't completely spicy but still had very good deep flavor. It had many pieces of tofu, zucchini, mushrooms, radishes/white carrots and pork. Like traditional Korean soup dishes, it came with a bowl of rice and even a side of banchan, a spicy pickled radish, which was good.

After moving here from NOLA which has amazing options for pho, I have been shocked/ disappointed by the lack of Pho in Chicago. This pho is much better than saigon sisters, although the meat is lacking a bit. i give props for the to go containers being bowls so its easier to eat. Definitely a repeat when i'm in the loop looking for pho

Similar to many other customers, I came here during a work lunch break - because it had a great Yelp rating, I actually walked 15 minutes just to try it. Green Apple offers both Vietnamese (Pho combinations with various toppings) and Korean (Sundubu, Bibimbap, Japchae) options.  This review is for the Beef Pho, since I didn't get to try the Korean food. Although the pho was quick and satisfied my cravings for Asian food, it was definitely not as good as Tank Noodle in Argyle. I was disappointed that they were pretty stingy with their portions - the bowl is filled with a lot of broth, but there's a tiny portion of noodles and meat. Although I wouldn't make the trip here again, it's not a bad option for lunch if you're already in the area.

Over the winter I was coming here once a week for lunch. They have THE BEST PHO in the Loop. I usually get the meatball (P7) or the steak (P9) pho on the menu. it's definitely worth the price because I'm usually full after having a delicious bowl of their soup. If you're downtown I highly recommend trying this place out. The only downside is there usually not a lot of seating where there located so try to have a late lunch when you can sit at a table.

Chicago, you deserve better South East Asian food. Your Thai places, your Vietnamese places - yow.  Green Apple is average for Chicago. Convenient location, fast service, and typical pho prices (8-9 dollars / bowl). On the Pho: You do not get much meat in the bowl, medium qtys of noodles, and a lot of broth. If you're desperate for pho, this isn't bad, but there are better places in the word - just not many in Chicago.

I was skeptical of food court pho. Also Korean pho. But the pho tai was well worth the price (good quantity & quality of meat, broth a little bland but they give plenty of sauce). Glad to know there's an okay pho place outside of uptown. Service was also really quick and friendly enough at 9am

The Pho is the best in The Loop that I've been able to find. I've only had the chicken and vegetable so I can't speak to the red meat options but they look good. Also I've never had the Korean options (japchae, bibimbap, etc) but they're definitely ordered less frequently by other patrons. The sprouts, cilantro, and like with the pho is a great touch. The location is hilarious. It's like on the second floor of a run down looking food court/sad excuse of a mall? I love it though; the perfect place to hide with a book and enjoy a long lunch break. Also accessible from the pedway for those brutal winter months.

I struggled a wee bit to get to this place (no this doesn't have anything to do with the 3 stars). I was excited to check this place out and when I found it I was cold and ready for some pho! Alright, menus is pretty small but of course all I wanted was pho. Put my order in (meatball pho with a mango smoothie). Really nice staff, they gave me a number and I went ahead and took a seat. They brought my food to the table (super nice). Alright now time for the eeeehhhh part. My bean sprouts looked old, they were a little brown, this was sad because I love my bean sprouts. The cilantro was also old, I know my cilantro, being part of a Mexican family you know when your cilantro is fresh. My limes, also old, I could barely squeeze any lime juice out. I proceeded to take my first bite, the broth was okay noodles seemed a little hard but it wasn't unbearable.  Meatballs were good except for the fact that I only got 4 :(  Overall it's a quick desperate pho fix if you are around that area.  Why is it that every time I eat pho everyone asks me if I need a fork....? Gahhhhh! I know my chopsticks well dammmmit!

This was my first time having Pho.  I had the P10, chicken and vegetables.  It was delicious!  Although I don't have anything to compare it to, I believe that this was a filling, affordable meal for downtown.  I do agree with some yelpers that there isn't much protein, but that's fine by me.  I would definitely get it again. Note - the line gets long around lunchtime during the week.

In an attempt to kill some time before my train left during a particularly frigid day in Chicago, I Yelped reviews of nearby Vietnamese places and came across this one.  The fact that it was a hole-in-the-wall in a food court only made it more appealing to me.  I hauled my ass over there and ordered the pho (please pronounce it correctly) and jap chae, both to-go, the latter to be eaten on my train ride home.   I'll be up front, I ordered the vegetarian pho, which some traditionalists might immediately reject.  It was good, it wasn't the best I've had, but I really enjoyed the tofu and broccoli, as well as the broth and noodles.   The jap chae, which is a Korean dish, was amazing!  I ate it on the train, trying not to spill it on the seat next to me the whole time I wolfed it down.  The glass noodles and beef were well seasoned, and the beef wasn't the fatty, grisly kind you often get in such establishments (one reason I ordered the vegetarian pho). I highly recommend this restaurant, although I would suggest getting take out.

I grew up in a city with amazing Asian food, so I constantly gripe about the lack of Asian food in Chicago. That having been said, this one is my go-to place for pho. Even with its small menu and unassuming demeanour, I think it tops any Vietnamese place up by Argyle. Pho - I don't know why they even have Korean food on the menu, because most people come here for the pho. The broth is the best I've had in the city, and the noodles are perfectly cooked. My only complaint is that they seem to be a little stingy on the ingredients - I never find more than a few tiny pieces of tendon or tripe on my pho. I've started ordering tendon and tripe on the side so they can't hide it in the broth and claim it's at the bottom. Also, their fruit smoothies are quite good. If you come here on a weekend, you'll probably find the location a little sketchy, but keep in mind that this is major hub in the Pedway so it makes sense that there's a random food court here. The place is never elegant, but it's pretty packed on a weekday lunch.

I tried the Kimchi Jigae - there was a piece of wire in the soup. Other than the wire, the jigae was nothing great.  Although the kimchi and tofu were good, the soup itself was just not that good.  Any HMart food court blows this place away. And there was the piece of wire (the type you find holding together a take-out food container) - could have used the meal without that. At the same meal, my co-worker got a Bibimbap that had the egg overcooked, the vegetables unpickled, and generally a subpar Gochujang. I wouldn't recommend Green Apple for the Korean food and won't be going back for Pho, unless I get a taste for some staples or nails in my soup.

I was hesitant on writing this review because I don't want too many people to find out about my little secret and wait long lines!  I've only had the pho soup but that's all you'll need to get because it's sooo good and filling.  I'm a big guy so for a soup to fill me up, it's a big deal.  Just ask for the P10 (chicken and vegetables) and thank me later.   By the way, it's at the 2nd floor of the little food court, above Olive.
finally some real asian food in the area with decent prices.  not some glorified asian-fusion watered down overpriced crap like everything else in this loop area.

First experience - Bibimbap. I have nothing to compare it to but it was delicious. The veggies were crisp and fresh, the chicken was great, brown rice perfectly cooked, but the egg was overdone. No run to the yolk. The portion wasnt too bad, although I could have used a bit more. The pho looked more filling.  I am definitely trying the Pho next time, and there WILL be a next time. If it hasn't been said enough times already, this is in a food court on the second floor to the left. Nothing fancy, cafeteria style seating, but does takeout.

As close to authentic korean soups, Kim chi stews, bibimbap, and cold noodle soup (mul naeng myun) as you can get without trekking to Koreatown (N Lincoln & waaaaaaaay north).  Excellent ban chans, too!  The food court is a little dumpy but ignore that, you're coming here for a legit korean fix!
I love the chicken and vegetable soup even though they go pretty light on the chicken.  I am a  soup connoisseur, this place passes the test with flying colors.

I come in here about once a week for Pho. It's a little hard to find but it's pretty much on the second floor of a food court on the corner of Clark and Lake. Don't let the atmosphere fool you...this is good Pho!  I usually get the vegetable pho which is divine. It's loaded with fresh veggies and tofu with the usual sides.  Also, the old man (I assume he's the owner) is the sweetest guy! This place is PHOntastic! :-D

Wow, I can't believe this place exists downtown in the loop! I have to say that it's better than the Ba Le on Washington since the noodles there were overcooked. This spot impresses me and you have to get here for lunch early because they do get quite a line. I felt bad because they seemed so understaffed. It looked like a family business of Koreans with the grandparents doing all kinds of work. They were assembling the food, making smoothies, picking up plates that were left on tables, cleaning, and cooking. My heart goes out to them because it looked like crazy busy was kicking their butts. We had to wait a while almost after we were finished with our meal before we got our drinks. It was worth it though, surprisingly good for a food court area. I will certainly be back, especially during the winter time when hot pho soup is much needed. Prices were reasonable and portions were just right.

Okay, as a disclaimer: I love Korean food. I've had it in various cities for years and really liked it. For the past few years, I've been vegetarian and had no problem getting vegetarian food at Korean places. So I've still enjoyed the cuisine anywhere I went. I was craving some Korean food and came across this place, saw the reviews and decided to venture there myself. I work near the Art Institute so it was kind of a trek for a lunch break, but I figured "what the heck, it's a nice day, I get to go for a walk, and good food will await me." I eat a lot of alternative and foreign food, and have found that many places with great dishes are total holes in the wall. So I was not remotely turned off by the modest setting. BUT the food did turn me off. I got the tofu jap chae and regretted it. The service was pretty decent. Within five minutes, I got my order and was excited to dig in. It looked appetizing, but I didn't enjoy it and here's why: I first dug into the salad which was in some sort of lime-green sauce. I at first thought it was kind of good. But the aftertaste was that of spoiled milk. So I refused to eat any more. I then went for the noodles. The taste itself was fine but the noodles were so damn oily that my stomach felt weird and I just felt disgusting like I was just consuming oil, and probably among the worst and cheapest oils with god know's how many trans fats. I've never had a Korean dish before that seemed so unhealthy. Ugh. But I was hungry and persisted for a while. I was also disappointed that the vegetables pretty much sucked. What you see in the picture I posted is pretty much all I got. The tofu was soft and okay. The vegetables were tiny shreds and sparse. So I was basically left with this heaping portion of oily noodles. I couldn't even finish. I felt like I wasted my money and was very disappointed. That being said, I was astounded by the good reviews. Maybe I just picked the one grossly oily, not-remotely-diverse item on the menu. In retrospect, I thought I should have gone with the bi bim bap, which I've always enjoyed at any Korean place I've been to. Or the pho, which I was eyeing. But I decided to try something different and it backfired. Maybe... MAYBE I'll go back sometime if I'm in the area and craving bi bim bap. But as for the jap chae, I'd steer clear. Honestly, there was nothing distinctly Korean about it at all and looked and tasted like something from an American-Chinese place like Panda Express and the like. It didn't come CLOSE to any other Korean place I've had. I understand it's the Loop and fast food but, like I said, it was like cheap, Americanized Chinese food with the word "Korean" slapped on it. Save your money and don't buy this item if you really want to eat at this place. I can't speak for the other dishes, but I wouldn't recommend the jap chae.

A good spot for a mid-day pho fix! Sometimes all you need to make life feel better is a steaming bowl of savory broth, meat, and noodles. One star down because Green Apple doesn't quite deliver quality like the authentic places in Uptown. The pho that is supposed to have all the fixin's is pretty light on the meat (minimal tripe, tendon), and the bean sprouts are sometimes a little brown. However, you'll still find me here at least every other week. I actually like getting the chicken and veggie pho because in my mind, the lean meat and vegetables make it healthier??  Aside from the pho, the Korean options here are pretty good too.  I really like the japchae (stir fried sweet potato noodles with vegetables and beef), and the gom tang (beef broth made from the bones) and bibimbap are good when the right craving hits.

The food court was definitely a turn off- but the food was fresh and tasty. It was my first time having pho, and I was looking forward to the fresh basil (they have cilantro) and the meat being raw so that u can cook it in the broth, but it was good for what it was. Affordable and huge portions!

4 stars; only because I ordered the pho dac biet($8.25 after tax), and though it was supposed to contain flank steak, brisket, tripe, and tendon; I was disappointed to find no tendon in my bowl. Other than that, the dish was phenomenal. And I will be returning, but next time I shall ask for extra tendon.

This is the second time I've been here and I got basically the same thing. I ordered the pho which wasn't exactly amazing but it works.  There aren't many pho places in the Loop and this place almost hits the spot when it's cold and miserable outside. The owners/workers are Korean so Korean food might be a better bet? The service is quite quick though!
A solid Bibimbop. Fresh ingredients, great customer service.
I love their pho. I stop by here once a week to get my pho fix and they never disappoint. Their Korean food is something to be less desired but still decent.

The pho was absolutely delicious and they gave a lot of it! The bibimbap was O.K.... nothing special. And I didn't like how it didn't come in the bowl in the picture, and instead in a to-go box even though it was for dining in. Will definitely come back when I crave pho!

When I first found out there was a fast food Vietnamese/Korean place serving Pho in the Loop, I was a bit skeptical. Although there are decent options in the Loop, I lower my standards for ethnic food in the Loop. After telling my Korean coworker/friend about it, we decided to check it out. Don't be put off by the area. It's in a small food court on the second floor but the food is good here.  We ordered a bowl of Pho and Gom Tang, which is Korean bone soup.  First of all, the portions were very generous and I like how they gave a side of Kkakdugi (I think...basically kim chee radishes) with it.   The Pho is definitely the best I have ever had in the Loop and beats the hell out of the other places I've had in the Loop. It is on par with those you will find on Argyle, and possibly even better than a few. The Gom Tang was the first time I'd ever had that.  It was light, but good. I asked my Korean friend what he thought of it and he said "Actually, it's pretty good.." I would recommend this place to anyone who likes Pho/basic Korean food, especially if they work around the area. I will be back to try more.

The food court and its location is a turn-off but that isn't going to stop me from my search for acceptable Asian food in the Loop. Green Apple is run by Koreans. I think that's a trustable sign.  I had the beef bibimbap for $7 and my friend had the pho for $8. Both portions are standard and rather generous, considering its downtown location. My bibimbap was served in a large plastic, carry-out container even though I had it dine-in. It had the usual contents of beef, cucumber, zucchini, spinach, bean sprouts, carrots, and semi-fried egg. The egg was slightly over-fried and the rice was a tidbit dry. The mildly spicy sauce served on the side was a good compliment to the dish. Certainly not the best bibimbap but it will do.

Not a bargain, and 90% of the stuff they say (online) is on their menu actually isn't (like the sushi, the soup I wanted, ANYTHING Japanese-y).  I tried the spicy chicken, which was chintzy portions and really not spicy at all, and got my friend the bi-bim-bap, which was also chintzy and kind of uninspired.  Also neither was a bargain, considering the portion size.  Whatever.  You don't know a place is pass or fail till you try it once (and this one was a fail).
First time coming here and couldn't be happier. Got the combination pho on this rainy/cold Chicago day, and it made all the difference. Big portions, super friendly staff, and this pho, DAMN!

Korean-run Green Apple serves both Korean and Vietnamese food. Of course, I came here for pho as part of my quest to eat pho in all 50 states. The day my friend Amanda and I came, we were suffering in the 20 degree weather. It wasn't until we arrived that I realized this was actually a food court location, and not a sit down restaurant. But whatever, I was seriously just happy to thaw out. In addition to standard Korean foods like bibimbap, bulgogi, and japchae, Green Apple offers 10 types of pho. I ordered Pho Tai, and Amanda ordered Pho Vegetable, at $7.45 a bowl. The food came out fast, within five minutes. The pho came in huge bowls, in fact, bowls that were too big for the serving. It looked kind of strange. The garnishes came in individual styrofoam containers. The first thing that popped out at me was that there was no basil for the pho. They put cilantro with the garnishes instead. This was the strangest thing; I've never seen that before. There's always basil for pho. Everything else was pretty standard. The broth flavor was pretty good- not too salty, not oily, flavorful. At the same time, there wasn't anything special about it. The noodles were great, and the meat tasted good, but I thought it strange that the meat was already cooked through when I got the pho. It was never any degree of pink, and as we all know, tai is rare steak that is added to the pho at the last second so it can cook in the broth. So, that was a bit disappointing. Amanda's Pho Vegetable came with tofu, broccoli, mushrooms, and carrots. She'd also ordered a side of kimchee, which was just a dollar. She said the pho was good- the broth didn't taste meaty to her, which complemented the vegetables. I had to stare at her for a second because she started mixing the kimchee with her pho- "Is that weird?" she asked. But hey, she said it tasted good together, so who am I to judge? I was still craving Korean food, and ended up ordering bulgogi to go for my dinner.  That dish was a pretty good choice, though. It came in your usual styrofoam container divided into three, with two compartments much smaller than the other. The largest compartment held the bulgogi, so it was a generous portion. I wished that they'd given me more rice though, since they only gave enough to fill one of the small compartments, and the other held a bit of salad. I had to keep in mind that Green Apple is predominantly Korean, and see that as the main reason for any discrepancies. At the same time, I guess I have to give them credit for giving me the feeling of a full pho restaurant experience - because when I got back to the hotel, I realized that my clothes definitely smelled of pho, haha. Anyway, we went to Green Apple because it has a four-star rating here on Yelp, making it the best rated pho location nearby. So even though I'm not their biggest fan, they still have plenty of others. Next time I go to Chicago, I will probably not return. Instead, I'd like to check out Banh Mi Express, also in the Loop. Rating Breakdown: Taste (9/14): Broth flavor- 4/5 Noodle & meat quality- 4/5 Garnish selection- 0/2 (no basil? you must be kidding me.) Portion size- 1/2 Restaurant (12/16): Service- 4/5 Cleanliness- 4/5 Atmosphere- 3/4 Speed of arrival- 2/2 Total: 22/30 Read more at  phoacrossamerica.com

Having recently moved to Chicago for graduate school (therefore explaining my Yelp hiatus), I was craving some Korean food.  In Hawaii, it wasn't very difficult to just drive to the nearest Yummy's or So Gong Dong, but in Chicago, Korean restaurants are pretty limited.  It was also the perfect time to try something new since my girlfriend was visiting during her spring break. Despite the gloomy weather, she and I caught the pink line and got off at the Clark/Lane stop, just a few meters away from our destination.  It was a good thing that we read prior Yelp reviews before arriving because there weren't any outdoor signs indicating this eatery's location.  On the street corner where Popeye's, McDonalds, and Subway were located, my girlfriend and I entered this foodcourt.  On the second floor of this dimly-lit foodcourt, was Green Apple.  We approached the counter and viewed the limited menu selection.  There were typical Korean goodies including bibimbap, japchae, and boogolgi, but there was also a selection of Vietnamese pho.  Having just been rained on, a nice hot bowl of pho sounded rather decent.  My girlfriend proceeded to order the japchae and beef bibimbap (choice of beef or chicken bibimbap).   The friendly worker took our order and handed us a number placard to place upon our table so that they could deliver it to us when our food was ready.   We found a small red table for two to sit down and patiently waited.  Within five minutes, our orders came.  The bibimbap came first and although it was presented inside a large take-out container, it wasn't filled to the brim as one might expect.  Instead, there was about a scoop or rice with beef and colorfully chopped vegetables.  There was also a side of gochujang, a Korean hot paste to mix with the bibimbap.  Although the portion size was small, the flavor and freshness of the vegetables definitely made up for it.   Next came the japchae.  Again, it came in a large take-out box and only two sections of the take-out box were filled.  This time, the large portion of the box was filled with a huge serving of japchae noodles and a small portion had a few cucumbers and lettuce.  The main star of this entree was definitely the japchae--seasoned with enough sesame oil so it wasn't too overbearing, the right amount of vegetables for that added crunch, and a peppering of sesame seeds.  The small salad was not worth eating especially since there was this fruity salad dressing that it was tossed in. Lastly was the pho.  For $8, there was a generous serving of pho.  It came in a large bowl accompanied with the garnishes of lime, bean sprouts, and parsley.  It also came with hoisin sauce and hot sauce to add to the soup.  The broth was full of flavor and had a very clean taste.  And although the meatball was a typical spaghetti meatball, the slices of beef were generous.   All in all, this was a terrific experience.  I will definitely frequent this place more when I crave Korean food.

I really enjoyed the Pho I ordered from Green Apple. It was a rainy winter day in Chicago and I was walking around the city on my first day of my first visit--meaning a lot of wrong turns on foot. This hot bowl of broth and noodles was necessary for me to keep up my day. The bowl was huge and such a good price. I hate Thai Basil as it has a very licorice flavor so I love  that Green Apple gives you cilantro as a condiment instead. The location was a bit strange but it was not off putting especially in the circumstance of refuge from the cold, rainy day.

YOU GUYS! I cannot stop eating here! I've now tried almost all of the different kinds of Pho, the bibimbap (both chicken and beef) and today I had the kimchi stew. My coworkers did not enjoy the smell of it, but I don't give a crap because it was super delicious and I want to eat it every day.  Enjoy the aroma friends, I've got some more pickled cabbage to eat.

This is REAL Korean food! I lived in Korea for two years, have had my fair share of Korean meals, and must say this is the real thing... with an adorable couple running the place, too!  Also, it's affordable - for once. Since Korean food is now "in", the prices have gone up everywhere. But this place is wonderful and offers great and authentic Bibimbap for $7. I highly recommend - especially as they're as true to local business as you can get. They deserve lots of patronage!

While munching on a granny smith apple this morning, I reminded myself that Green Apple had been in my bookmarks for some months now. This wintry weather seemed like the perfect time to indulge in a steaming bowl of pho. Green Apple is definitely a spot that you'd only know about if you worked in the building or someone told you about it (or in this case, Yelp). It's located on the second floor of a modest office building food court. First of all, I'm far from knowledgeable about pho and if you told me a few months ago that I'd even be entertaining the thought of eating pho from a food court (:::shudders:::), I'd have probably laughed in your face. Still, I've learned to not judge a book by its cover when if comes to food. And GA is in the same food court at Olive Mediterranean Grill (which I've also tried and found to be more than decent) so I figured it couldn't hurt to give it a shot. I trudged over there in the sleet and slush hoping to be rewarded for my perseverance and I was pleasantly surprised. The order taker was very friendly and there were several options of pho from which to choose, as well as some Korean items like bibimbap and bulgogi. I settled on the chicken pho with tofu and vegetables and my order was quickly ready, with the noodles and accompaniments (cilantro, jalapeno, bean sprouts and lime) packaged separately. Again, I'm by no means an expert on pho, so I'll just review this on its own merits and not compare it to other pho I've had (which admittedly hasn't been much) and say that it was pretty delicious. The chicken was all white meat, and very tender, and the vegetables (broccoli, cauliflower, carrots and mushrooms) were still a bit crisp. The broth (which stayed hot as f*ck for almost 40 minutes) had deep, rich flavor. The huge bowl of soup and all the fixin's set me back just under $10 and I feel very satisfied. And I'm always happy to pay $10 or less for lunch because it doesn't happen very often. If this is legit pho, then I'm down. Even if it's not legit pho, I'm still down. 3.5 stars.

Huh. I am somewhat tempted to go back and order something else at Green Apple after reading so many positive reviews. After all, it is no small feat to find good Korean food/pho downtown. Maybe I just chose the wrong dish on a wrong day- I had a bowl of their pho and did not enjoy it. The portion was big and the meat pretty tasty. However, the noodles were really chewy, the broth bland, and everything was lukewarm. Definitely failed to impress. As I left I mentally kicked myself for trying pho anywhere that isn't Argyle, considering I live a less than 10min bus ride from the neighborhood, but when a craving hits, it hits hard. I am reluctant to give their pho another shot but maybe I'll have better luck with their Korean offerings...an updated review to come later, perhaps!

Holy Smoke!!!  A legit Pho place in the loop!   Thank you Yelp for assuring me this place exists and helping me find it.  It's behind the McD's, in the center of a building, in a food court, upstairs.  Funnily enough, it's ON the Chicago Pedway system, that pretty much no one knows about either!  This Pho tastes straight from Argyle.  I got the My Pho with beef and meatballs.  It's a large bowl fresh rice noodles and onions. The meatballs were awesome.  I loaded my pho bowl up with fresh cilantro and sprouts, hot sauce, and a soy based sweet sauce.  Plus a little extra hot sauce which sure warms you up from 16 degrees! It's PHOnomenal!   Seriously, great Loop Lunch.

I was REALLY skeptical that this place would be any good. First of all, it's named "Green Apple Grill & More". huh? Secondly, it serves yogurt smoothies, korean and vietnamese food, and no apples. Thirdly, it's in a food court with Popeyes Chicken. But fear not, their pho is really good. The emloyees even bring your food to you. Each order comes with the traditional side of bean sprouts, lime, peppers and cilantro. Plus 3 samples of sauce: plum, chilli peppers and sriracha. Good stuff on a cold day.

Pho: Pretty good. It was hard for me to find a decent pho place in downtown chicago. I think this is the only clean and delicious pho that i could find so far. Bibimbap: Love it!  Service: It is in the food court, but they bring your food to your table after ordering. It is a treat!

I've been disappointed by the authenticity of ethnic food in the River North/Loop area, but Green Apple makes me very, very happy. The jap chae is gigantic, and amazing - one order will feed me for several meals. And pho, swoon! Even my non-adventurous coworkers have asked what I ordered because it smelled so delightful. They give you all the fixings on the side, to make your delicious pho have such flavor complexity. And, it's cheap. The area's a little food court, so I get my food to go, but it's very reasonably priced, and the food is always steaming hot and the staff polite.

This place is a hidden gem.  I ordered the bim bi bop with beef and it was delicious.  A very nice, spicy loop lunch location.  The price is very reasonable too, another rare thing in the loop.  Sometimes it can be hard to find seating upstairs, but if you wait a few minutes something will open up.  I would recommend this restaurant for any fan of Korean food.  The food comes out quickly too.
This place is great! It's in a scummy food court, but the Pho was bomb! I got the Pho #5 and my buddy got the Pho#2. We both thought it was great. Worth plenty of food for 8 bucks as well. GO!
Excellent pho, got the chicken and vegetables and everything tasted fresh.  Try sitting down on the first floor,as the smell from Popeyes cooking can ruin the experience.
Good korean food and pho. Its on a run down good court but food is good and very reasonable.

Just went here for the first time and I am so glad I found this.  Its a little bit of a hike from the Illinois Center, but well worth it. Had one of the pho soups and it was huge for $8, and awesome as far as pho goes. Will definitely be going back to try their Korean options. My only complaint is that it might be too cold for me to hike here in winter (although it is connected to the pedway via the Leo Burnett building.

My first pho experience happened to be here. Not sure if this is a good place to start for this wonderful dish but it just happened that way. I was walking down Mich Ave with a certain lovely lady, and pho was brought up,  and Yelp brought us here. The food court location (entrance is located on Lake right next to the McDonald's) made me a bit skeptical at first. The portions were pho-nominal and it all tasted great to me. I particularly enjoyed the brown sauce that it came with (similar to teriyaki) for mixing in. Bean sprouts and Asian basil came on the side.  I enjoyed my first pho experience here. Now I will be searching out the next best place to get it in the city as winter is upon us. Truly warms the soul.

This is the place to go for good Korean food in the loop. They don't have much variety, but what they DO offer (gomtang, yukgaejang, bulgogi) is very, very good. Actually, when I first came here I was blown away by the quality of the food. It's not just good Korean for the Loop, it's good PERIOD. Especially the gomtang. Get the gomtang.  Of course if you're not a Korean food type of guy, try the pho. Best pho in the loop. It's not quite Argyle, but more than adequate to satisfy a lunchtime craving. Beats out Saigon Sisters by far.

I went to Green Apple today because I had a craving for bibimbap. I was apprehensive though since some reviews said it was in a scary food court. So with my big girl pants on, I strolled into the ... not-very-scary food court. Sparse, not elegantly decorated, but definitely not scary. At. All. Onto the food: I ordered and my bibimbap was ready pretty quickly (I went after the lunch rush, though). It was delicious! I scarfed it down so fast I probably scared the guy across from me eating his pho. The rice and beef were full of flavor, and the veggies complemented them well with their fresh taste. Mixing all the items up together made each mouthful a tasty surprise. I have never had pho, but I will try it the next time. I'm not an expert on Korean food but if you have a craving for it, this place will satisfy.
