When my friend mentioned a place in the loop where I could get my Korean food fix, I was thrilled. I love Korean food and if I'm not making it myself, the only times I could have it are the weekends (I rarely go get it on the weeknights since I don't want to battle traffic going to the north side of Chicago where the majority of Korean restaurants are).  Green Apple offers Korean, Vietnamese and frozen yogurt...a bit of an odd smorgasbord but I was definitely still up for giving it a try.  I had their mul nangmyun - decent and definitely did the trick. My friend had the bibimbap - small portion but tasty. I will definitely be back to try the pho and their other Korean dishes.

If you're in the Loop and craving some Korean food, your choices are pretty limited; you have Korean Express, Square Bowl, and Green Apple. After having Green Apple on my list for months, I finally gave it a shot today with a friend who probably loves Korean food more than I do. The food court that it's located in won't win any awards for design or cleanliness, but it gets the job done. So does Green Apple. I ordered the Bimbimbap with brown rice (yes, they do have brown rice here!) and my friend ordered the Mul Nangmyun. The portion size for the bibimbap was definitely smaller (by over half) compared to Korean Express, but it definitely tasted better and fresher. They overfried the egg, resulting in a hard-boiled like yolk, but everything else was better than I expected. I consider that a win. I also tried some of my friend's nangmyun, and it was definitely refreshing. Not the most flavorful of broths, but they give you a nice side of ggakdoogi which was also pretty decent.  All in all, when you're looking for Korean in the Loop, you don't go wrong with this place. I'm looking forward to trying the Pho and Korean jigaes (stews) as the cold weather approaches.

Bad location, pretty good food! I got some kind of Korean bip-something (suggested by a coworker) and it comes in a container with varies veggies, rice, an egg, and some chicken that is somewhat spicy. Also, they have a pretty good Korean BBQ sauce for you to dip your chicken in. If you walk into that food court, you will understand the surprise. Give it a try. I think you'll like it, too!
The only plentiful kimchi side dishes in the area.  The Korean soups are great and authentic. Pho is not bad but not the same as its Vietnamese ancestry.   Yogurt portion is more than enough.

Great place for a quick Korean fix! I had some Bulgogi (with double meat, only $1 more), and the quality was very good for a fast food place. The meal was a little light on vegetables for my taste, but it was very filling considering the ~$8.80 price tag. The beef was marinated and flavorful, and very tender. Side salad was "Okay" - basically just some lettuce and dressing. I yet have to try some of the other dishes, but it looks like I will definitely be back :).

As prescribed by yelp, my friend order Pho#5 and I ordered Naeng-Myon (Korean Cold Buckwheat Noodles). To make ordering not be a sh@tshow, I ordered for myself and my friend in Korea :) Everything was pretty good. We didn't see any creepy janitors around :D  Reason for not giving another star? Well, I am going to come back and try some of their other Korean food. I consider Naeng-Myon to be one of the easiest dishes to make and I know the difference between the phenomenal kind and the ordinary kind you just find at the local food court. The kind I ate was just like the kind I had at the food court back in Seoul.  Something in me kind of wonders though...would it take a lot of money to develop a good nice rich beef broth? Because that is the secret between the phenomenal kind and the mediocre Naeng-Myon

Five stars for just what I needed...pho on a shopping trip!  It was a depressing food court, as Jessie F. says, but worth the trip inside.  Seems to get a lot of neighborhood people, though, which speaks highly of its food.  The service was wonderful.  The proprietor even brought me a "real" bowl when he found I was going to eat at the little table on the mall side, instead of carry out.

I ate here around September. I was thrilled at first because I finally found a Korean restaurant. After hearing so many good things about Bibimbap and working up an appetite I decided and ordered the Bibimbap. Then I  received a pre-made container of vegetables with my choice of either chicken or beef (sauce on the side). I tried everything seperately, at first, for taste and then decided to mix it up. Didn't enjoy the sauce. It had a burnt taste but otherwise the food was good. The restaurant is apart of a food court and the tables are sparse, if you're eating inside. Besides the sauce, my only complaint was the staring. Some of the workers would look at me when I wasn't looking. I have no idea what they were looking for but thanks for the food!  P.S. for future eaters, the restaurant is up stairs
Pho was very good. The Jap Chae was  tasty, but the place was so hard to find that it almost wasn't worth the effort.

As many have mentioned, this place has multiple names and is located in a food court that reeks of fast food and depressing times.  If you can overlook these things, then you will be able to get pho in the Loop, which is nearly impossible.   As I'm not a pho expert, I can't speak to whether or not this is authentic.  HOWEVER, I always leave full and in want of a nap rather than returning to work.  The staff is so nice!  They have mango smoothies!  The bibimbap is on par with it being a food court, but not a shady one!  So, just go here, try it out, you will definitely enjoy it, even if your clothes smell like pho/Popeye's/McDonald's/orange chicken afterwards.  What's the alternative?  Getting the food carryout so that you can enjoy your pho, jap chae, bibimbap and smoothie on the go. So try ti out! They also have  a FroYo machine, which I am going to check out when it gets warmer.  But seriously, this is the only reason to ever come to this food court.
Great phos for a random Korean place in the loop, though its doused with MSG, I was pretty thirsty afterwards

If you're brave enough to venture inside this terrifying food court, you're in for a treat! As soon as you walk into the food court, you're hit with a pungent wave of grease and chicken skin. Pretty standard for one that houses both a McDonald's AND a Popeyes. With the sunlight filtering in from the windows above, you can basically see all the smoke wafting about.  Wave your way through the seats (which are always filled with...unique people around lunchtime), make your way up the stairs and turn left. Tada! You've made it! Green Apple is the biggest store on the 2nd floor and has its own seating area. You can order a large variety of food there. They have Korean dishes, stuffed potatoes, Pho, AND frozen yogurt. Heaven for a fro-yo addict like me! I have yet to try the Korean dishes and the stuffed potatoes. My favorite Pho bowl is #1, which is the standard beef one containing flank, steak, shank, tendon, and tripe. There's also vegetarian, seafood, chicken, and combination bowls available. Mmmm. Haven't tried the vegetarian Pho personally but one of my friends has and commented on how rich the soup tasted even though it was meat free. I think the pho prices range from $7.45-$8.45. The owner always gives me a free soda with my order! The quality of the Pho is fantastic. As a Chicago resident, I know how hard it is to find good noodles at a good price in the city. The bowls come with a LOT of meat - they don't skimp on portions! You also get a box with sprouts, jalapeno slices, a lime wedge, basil, and cilantro as well as containers of Sriracha, Hoisin, and a chunkier spicy sauce (I don't know what it's called but it kind of looks like salsa?)  The soup is warm, satisfying, and makes me want to stand up and sing Hakuna Matata. I'm drooling right now just thinking about it...YUM. Noodles are light and slurpable. I'm a really big fan of how large their serving sizes are. When I dine in with a friend, we usually split a bowl of Pho, which leaves us just enough room to get their frozen yogurt for dessert. When I order to go, I'll eat half of it for lunch and have enough leftovers for dinner.  Note: when you buy Pho to-go, you get 3 separate boxes: one for the noodles, one for the soup/meat, and one for your toppings/condiments! TIPS: 1) Grab a punch card! They're in a small tray right by the registers. You get one punch for each pho bowl/lunch item you buy, and you get a free lunch item after 10 punches! 2) Ladies: if you go to this food court by yourself, be careful! Wear a fake wedding ring! Don't smile at strangers! There's a janitor here that is CREEPY AS FUHHH. I don't run into him very often, but when I do, it's always on those days that I'm alone. Sometimes when I order to-go and I'm just standing around waiting, he'll come up to me and ask where my boyfriend/husband is, if I'm married, if I want him to take me out.....SCARY. If it's not too busy, the owner will chat with you while you're waiting, which will deter the creep. Or, if you're standing by the tables, a dude in a suit might tell him to back off. Pretty diverse customer base here. 3) You can bring your laptops/tablets here since there's free WiFi! I mean, it's from the McDonald's downstairs but hey, it works. 4) If the 2-person tables along the sides are free, sit there! It's a prime spot for people-watching. If you're into observing weird habits or enjoy sites like People of Walmart, you'll have a great time looking at all the...interesting people down below :)

My first opinion is this place is trying to do too much... Frozen Yogurt... Korean.. and Viet? Come on! Which one are you actually specializing in? The food was decent (considering it's location), my expectation for Asian food in downtown isn't very high. I ordered the bulgoki, and my friend ordered the pho. The bulgoki was okay, but a bit on the smaller portion? Or maybe I was just really hungry that day. Would come back, but not that often.
Depressing, wanna-be food court overflowing with frier smoke and morbidly obese shoving mcdonalds  and popeyes down their gullets. To what length will you go to for the best pho in Chicago?

I ordered the Chicken with Vegetables Pho twice here, and it was excellent.  Both times were to-go and included separate containers for the chicken vegetable broth, noodles, and greens to mix in.  I will admit, with all the containers you look like a pig.   It will also have you feeling like a pig, as it is quite messy, and I have to transfer and mix in a much sturdier bowl when I get back to the office.   It is so much food, it lasts me 2 lunches.  I love leftovers, especially at $9 total for this amount of food :)  Be warned it is a little spicy with the jalapenos and side sauces - gets your nose and eyes watering a bit.  Mmmmm, sniff sniff.   It  does take a few minutes for them to prepare, so don't be in a hurry.  They also have good frozen yogurt with fresh fruit toppings.   On the corner of Lake and Clark, this place is tucked away on the second level above the sushi and Mediterranean places, and of course Popeyes and Mcdonalds.  Such an odd selection in this food court - haha!

This stand has several names: Big Pho, Green Apple, Korean BBQ, etc. haha, they need to consolidate the names for their own sake. I had to enter in the address of the food court so that I could figure out how to write a review for this place.  I'm not a connoisseur of Pho or Vietnamese food in general (as the other reviewers seem to be), but I do know good, hearty soup. This place has it and its cheap too. I think all the Pho runs between $7 and $9. I plan on trying the other stuff on their menu, but for right now, the cold weather place I'll be hitting up for delish Pho is Green Apple/BigPho/Korean BBQ Grill ;)  The staff is  great and so polite. I've yet to have a bad experience here.

I ordered the chicken pho.  The soup was delicious - flavorful but not salty, loaded with stuff, and a large portion.   The service, though, was a bit slow and disorganized.  I waited 10-15 minutes for my pho. I will definitely be back for the tasty pho, which is so elusive in these here parts.  I might try to avoid the lunch-hour rush.

Finding pho in and around the loop is harder than trying to find a company that Apple hasn't sued yet. After a 12 hour drinkfest the night prior, I had my mind on the pho and the pho on my mind. I had no choice but to roll the dice on this for prior to this visit, my experience with Korean pho had been less than stellar. Right after ordering, I realized they also had Gom Tang which is a Korean beef bone stock soup which I would've ordered had I known they had it on the menu. After tasting the broth of the pho, I no longer regretted my decision. I swear their broth tastes like Gom Tang with a few more herbs, and though it was far from legitimate, the broth was stocky and had a good depth that cured any and all ailments within me. Although the loop history shows otherwise, I am hopeful that this establishment will be open on weekends.

Love love this place.  I had a fierce craving for pho earlier and knew that finding a steaming bowl of beef soup deliciousness would be nearly impossible in the Loop. Thank goodness for Yelp (and for Tom and Angie X's review). Within 15 minutes, I was back at my desk and devouring the #9 steak pho. Mmm. I was also psyched to find that Green Apple offers up some of my favorite Korean dishes, like soondubu, chap chae, and bibimbap. A place that sells pho + Korean food + frozen yogurt is like something I would have come up with in my wildest dreams. Enough said. I still have to come back to try the Korean food, but I'm pretty sure I've found my newest fave lunch spot.

Blink and you might miss this place. Situated above the  Mcdonalds and Popeyes, I've passed by this place who knows how many times but never noticed it until one day, bam! As this place is only 2 mins from my apt I was somewhat disappointed that I had not discovered it as I've been looking for a close by Pho restaurant. The restaurant itself has somewhat of an identify issue, it has a few names over its 2 counters. I believe the one on the right is just for pho whereas the one on the left is for the korean fixings. So ambience, definitely lunch-spot type of feel, you can sit there are eat while looking over the people rushing in and out of the fastfood joints in the plaza below. Food: 1) Pho- broth was good albeit a little cloudy, the beef was tender and delicious, the condiments were right on in terms of amount and freshness and the noodles were pretty good and standard. Now just to find Pho in the loop is already a challenge in itself, so I wasn't expecting the most amazing pho but it was definitely more than good enough to fill that craving. 2) Bibimbap- they have an assembly line setup where they put your choice of meat in a pre-made bibimbap container and slap one some condiments. Now at the time I picked it up it did not look appetizing but after tasting it, I have to say it's alot better than it looks, but by no means great. 3) Spicy Chicken- better than the bibimbap, comes with fried rice. For a nice cheap lunch in the loop you really can't go wrong with this place especially if you're in the mood for some Pho.

This is a good little sandwich/Japanese food shop.  The sandwich are super fresh and they have 3 varieties of wraps and about 7 choices of bread.  I usually just get a BLT on a seven grain roll and a side of fresh strawberries.  No frills, just a good solid lunch for around 6 bucks.
